channel.title: I know you've been watching porn
channel.description:
Hello, it's been a while.
I found an interesting article and demonstration of how any website can log all the sites its visitors have visited using a well known CSS exploit that has been around for quite a while now. Check out http://www.pullyour.info
Think of the possibilities. You have a popular website. By scanning the visitor's browsing history, you profile him and show the right items on say, eBay, with your affiliate link on it. It has been rumoured that Dell used to do that for their own products.
Jagex could also implement this. They could scan for your browsing history against a blacklist of websites and ban/flag your accounts accordingly. For example online poker clients use this to try to determine if the player is using a bot.
I do realise this could be old news as I've been out the scene for a few years.

item.source: I know you've been watching porn

item.title: I know you've been watching porn
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

// if has font size 60px (associated with a:visited)
	if(typeof(l.style)!= "undefined" && ((typeof(l.currentStyle) != "undefined" && l.currentStyle.fontSize == "60px") || (typeof(document.defaultView) != "undefined" && (document.defaultView.getComputedStyle(l,null)).fontSize == "60px")))
		// has visited
		return true;
 
	// has not visited
	return false;

I never would have thought of that…So this is the browsers fault, it should not make the visual indication that a link has been visited controllable in CSS.

It is also worth noting that this technically doesn’t dump your history, it has to crawl common sites and inject a link into the page to see if the link will have a:visited CSS attributes. Of course this is just fine for someone like Jagex who would use a blacklist.

Good thing most browsers allow you to disable this!

Read full topic
